children: A 59-year-old man recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus undergoes a comprehensive ophthalmologic examination.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The patient has proliferative diabetic retinopathy. The funduscopic image shows neovascularization, cotton-wool spots, and retinal hemorrhage. Preproliferative retinopathy is manifested by cotton-wool spots, which indicate retinal infarcts. This ischemia eventually provides a stimulus for the growth of new blood vessels (neovascularization). The vessels that form are abnormal in both appearance and structure and are prone to hemorrhage. In proliferative retinopathy, blood vessel fragility can lead to significant retinal and vitreous hemorrhage. Edema of the retina may also occur.
